Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: See, e.g., Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (parental rights and the best-interests standard); and established Massachusetts practice that custody modifications rest within the trial court’s discretion where circumstances materially affect the children’s welfare.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel does address parental constitutional rights versus a bare ‘best interests of the child’ standard, so it is relevant to the first half of the parenthetical (“parental rights and the best-interests standard”). However, it says nothing about “established Massachusetts practice” or about custody *modifications* being entrusted to the trial court’s discretion when circumstances materially affect a child’s welfare. That second clause is a distinct, state‑law proposition not discussed in this federal grandparent-visitation decision, so Troxel does not support the full proposition as written.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The liberty interest at issue in this case—the interest of parents in the care, custody, and control of their children—is perhaps the oldest of the fundamental liberty interests recognized by this Court. … [T]he Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects the fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children. … [T]he Washington nonparental visitation statute…places the best-interest determination solely in the hands of the judge.” (530 U.S. at 65–67).

Commonwealth v. Shannon, 427 Mass. 280 (.proposition: (Notes: Petitioner cites the foregoing statutes and case authorities for the legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions.
Commonwealth v. Shannon, 427 Mass. 280 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Commonwealth v. Shannon deals with Fourth Amendment and art. 14 standards for vehicle stops, frisks, and searches based on a report of a sawed-off shotgun, plus related Miranda/custodial issues. It does not address family-law doctrines such as custody modification, emergency custody or protective relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders in the domestic‑relations sense, or child‑protective interventions. Citing this case for “legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child‑protective interventions” mischaracterizes its subject matter and holding.
Commonwealth v. Shannon, 427 Mass. 280 (.relevant_excerpt: “The issue is whether the police had a constitutionally sufficient basis to stop the car, order the four men out and frisk them for weapons, and then examine the car’s interior for a weapon which had been described as a possible sawed-off shotgun… We conclude that the information received by the police justified their conduct because reliable information that someone might be carrying a sawed-off shotgun stands on a much different footing than a report that someone might be carrying a handgun.”

Doe v. Department of Social Services, 43.raw_text: Doe v. Department of Social Services, 433 Mass. 19 (2001)
Doe v. Department of Social Services, 43.proposition: (Notes: Petitioner cites the foregoing statutes and case authorities for the legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions.
Doe v. Department of Social Services, 43.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts criminal homicide case addressing delayed disclosure of evidence, admissibility of organized-crime-related evidence, prosecutor’s argument, and G.L. c. 278, § 33E review. It does not concern family law, custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, or child-protective interventions. The petitioner’s use of this citation for standards in those areas is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding of the case.
Doe v. Department of Social Services, 43.relevant_excerpt: The defendant, John Stote, was convicted of murder in the first degree. He appealed from the conviction to this court. During the pendency of this appeal, the defendant was granted leave by a single justice to file a motion for a new trial, which the defendant did, alleging the existence of newly discovered evidence sufficient to warrant a new trial. The trial judge denied this motion, and the defendant appealed. Both appeals are consolidated before this court.

Lynch v. Lynch, 431 Mass. 606 (2000).proposition: (Notes: Petitioner cites the foregoing statutes and case authorities for the legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions.
Lynch v. Lynch, 431 Mass. 606 (2000).support_reasoning: The proposition describes Lynch v. Lynch as authority on custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions. The opinion provided is not a domestic relations or custody case at all; it is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court decision addressing subject-matter jurisdiction and monetary limits in District Court summary process (landlord–tenant) actions under St. 1996, c. 358. It does not discuss family-law standards, custody, visitation, restraining orders, or child-protective measures, so it does not support the cited proposition.
Lynch v. Lynch, 431 Mass. 606 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “In this case…we must decide whether the jurisdictional limits outlined in St. 1996, c. 358, apply to summary process actions. In a summary process action brought in the District Court the plaintiff obtained a judgment for possession and money damages… The defendant’s motion to dismiss the judgment for damages was allowed without prejudice for lack of subject matter jurisdiction… We hold that the jurisdiction limits in St. 1996, c. 358, apply to summary process actions and that the District Court had the power to vacate the judgment for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.”

Dwyer v. Dwyer, 410 Mass. 627 (1991).proposition: (Notes: Petitioner cites the foregoing statutes and case authorities for the legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions.
Dwyer v. Dwyer, 410 Mass. 627 (1991).case_name: Salem Hospital v. Commissioner of Public Welfare
Dwyer v. Dwyer, 410 Mass. 627 (1991).support_reasoning: This case deals exclusively with Medicaid eligibility for a nonresident alien and the validity of Massachusetts residency regulations under 42 U.S.C. § 1396b(v). It does not address custody modification, emergency family‑law relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, or child‑protective interventions. Using it as authority for those family-law standards mis-cites the opinion and is not supported by its holding or reasoning.
Dwyer v. Dwyer, 410 Mass. 627 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “The question litigated in the Superior Court, and the sole question on appeal, is whether the regulations, which expressly exclude persons in Stovropoulou’s circumstances from Medicaid benefits to pay for emergency medical treatment, are valid in light of 42 U.S.C. § 1396b (v). … We hold that the Commonwealth’s residency requirement for applicants or recipients seeking Medicaid benefits to pay for emergency medical treatment does not violate 42 U.S.C. § 1396b (v).”

Goggins v. Goggins, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 31.proposition: (Notes: Petitioner cites the foregoing statutes and case authorities for the legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions.
Goggins v. Goggins, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 31.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns legal standards for custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions. Goggins v. Goggins is a Massachusetts Appeals Court decision about brokerage contracts, bad faith revocation, interference with advantageous relations, and Chapter 93A business claims. It does not address family law, child custody, visitation, restraining orders, or child-protective procedures, so it cannot support the stated proposition.
Goggins v. Goggins, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 31.relevant_excerpt: The judge was warranted in concluding in essence that Bump was the victim of misrepresentations and concealment of material facts which caused him to suffer losses, and that such conduct by Robbins, on behalf of LRC, constituted “unfair or deceptive acts” in a business context. G. L. c. 93A §§ 2(a) and 11. ... The case is remanded to the trial judge in the Superior Court to determine damages against LRC and MRC on the c. 93A claim and whether there should be multiple damages, all on the basis of the evidence already received.

Wong v. Wong, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (198.raw_text: Wong v. Wong, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (1987)
Wong v. Wong, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (198.proposition: (Notes: Petitioner cites the foregoing statutes and case authorities for the legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions.
Wong v. Wong, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion in Wong v. Wong (actually a criminal civil-rights case under G.L. c. 265, § 37, despite the caption here) deals exclusively with whether that statute is unconstitutionally vague and whether the evidence was sufficient to sustain convictions for racially motivated assaults. It does not address family-law issues such as custody modification standards, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders in a domestic context, or child-protective interventions. Therefore, it does not support the proposition for which it is being cited.
Wong v. Wong, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant argues that G. L. c. 265, § 37, is unconstitutionally vague… We adopt this reasoning of the Screws decision and apply it to G. L. c. 265, § 37… We hold that the statute is not unconstitutionally vague… The defendant also argues that the evidence was insufficient to show… that he acted wilfully. … The evidence was also sufficient to warrant a finding that the defendant acted wilfully.”

In re Marriage of Smith, 409 Mass. 246 (.raw_text: In re Marriage of Smith, 409 Mass. 246 (1991)
In re Marriage of Smith, 409 Mass. 246 (.proposition: (Notes: Petitioner cites the foregoing statutes and case authorities for the legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions.
In re Marriage of Smith, 409 Mass. 246 (.support_reasoning: This opinion (Riley v. Presnell, 409 Mass. 239) concerns accrual of a psychotherapist‑malpractice claim and application of the discovery rule to the statute of limitations. It does not involve family law, custody modification standards, emergency custody relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, or child‑protective interventions. Therefore it does not provide authority for the custody‑related legal standards described in the proposition and is mis-cited for that purpose.
In re Marriage of Smith, 409 Mass. 246 (.relevant_excerpt: "This case requires us to determine whether and in what manner the so‑called ‘discovery rule’ affects the accrual of a malpractice action against a psychotherapist for purposes of the statute of limitations. We hold that an action against a psychotherapist for malpractice does not accrue, and therefore the statute of limitations does not begin to run, until the plaintiff knew or reasonably should have known that he may have suffered injury because of the psychotherapist's conduct."

Clarke v. Clarke, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 735.raw_text: Clarke v. Clarke, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 735 (2000)
Clarke v. Clarke, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 735.proposition: (Notes: Petitioner cites the foregoing statutes and case authorities for the legal standards applicable to custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, and child-protective interventions.
Clarke v. Clarke, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 735.support_reasoning: The opinion in Clarke v. Clarke (actually NationsBanc v. Eisenhauer in the provided text) concerns mortgage discharge, mistake in cancellation of a note, evidentiary rulings on business records, and appointment/compensation of a guardian ad litem for an incompetent party in a civil real estate/title action. It does not address custody modification, emergency relief, supervised visitation, restraining orders, or child-protective interventions. Therefore it cannot be proper authority for the family-law standards listed in the proposition.
Clarke v. Clarke, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 735.relevant_excerpt: “On June 14, 1995, at a pretrial conference, Mary represented that Paul was incompetent because of a mental illness and therefore was unable to defend the action brought by NationsBanc. As a result of an investigation into Paul’s condition, a judge, on August 11, 1995, appointed Henry H. Thayer as guardian ad litem (guardian) for Paul… As to the guardian ad litem’s expenses, including counsel fees, G. L. c. 201, § 35, authorizes the judge to determine the reasonable expenses including compensation and counsel fees of the guardian ad litem.”
